text: and in terms of though some of the
backroom maneuvers we know that during
some of the masa nations some people
have talked about being frightened of
having you as leader why do you think
that's the case I don't know you know
for me what I really wanted to do was an
honorable campaign that talked about the
great future I think we can have outside
of the EU and my desire to take us
forward I'm really not interested in
other people's kind of tactics or
whatever I just want an honorable
campaign but do you feel that there has
been a sort of operation to stop you
many of your colleagues have talked
about stop LEDs and we saw that in a
rather an extraordinary text message
that in marriage last night that is
going on amongst your colleagues again
you know I don't I'm not interested in
that it doesn't bother me because it's
just not it's not honorable so you know
I just up to me I think what people want
in this country is somebody that says
what they mean means what they say acts
with integrity I think that's what
people want and so you know that's what
I'm trying to do and I'm not really
interested in anything else are you
disappointed though about how quickly
this race has turned into the usual sort
of backroom plotting attempts to push
and shove people's loyalties around yes
of course I am yeah I mean it is
disappointing and you know one of the
things I would hope to do as Prime
Minister would be to change that from
the top you know by setting setting an
example if I can say that in terms of
then of setting that example there has
been confusion about your career before
you came into Parliament some people
have suggested you've tried to mislead
people there's been a suggestion that
you changed your CV do you want to
clarify I mean that I've not changed my
CV I have had 25 years in finance I
spent the best part of 10 years in bzw
in Barclays and the best part of 10
years in Invesco perpetual those are the
two longest periods I spent anywhere
in-between times I set up a funds
management company I started life as a
trainee broker on the London metals
exchange working for a big American
brokerage firm by the way I've also had
a part-time job in
Sainsbury's I started life as a 14 year
old silver service waitress and I ran
for a summer a restaurant in a hotel so
you know my CV is incredibly varied and
it's all absolutely true and you know I
don't I think this is you know
ridiculous in my CV is exactly as I've
set it out but one of your former
colleagues claims that you changed your
title from chief investment officer to
senior investment officer very different
jobs one responsible for hundreds of
pounds one a very different role there's
also a suggestion that you said you were
the managing director of an investment
fund the managing director of future and
fund management Companies House suggests
you were the marketing director now are
those claims that you've altered or
maybe slightly embellish your experience
wrong they would you like to clarify
yeah I would like to clarify yes I was
managing director of DiPietro and Varma
is a start-up funds management company
and I was managing director and what was
the other one I was a jet age investment
officer I was always very clear I was
senior investment officer working very
closely with the chief investment
officer I've been very clear I am NOT a
funds manager I was in Barclays and Visa
W managing huge teams of people and
large budgets and responsible for the
trade trading relationships well you
know to be very careful not to mislead
Barclays is a very big player in the
large corporate and institutional
banking world or it was when I was there
a long time ago now and so the trading
relationships are enormous billions and
billions and billions of pounds so when
I was there as the financial
institutions director responsible for UK
banking relationships the responsibility
was for billions of pounds of trading
lines and facilities to those companies
but to be completely clear and forgive
me for going into details very important
you were managing relationships rather
than the money itself because I've never
been a farmer I've never said I was a
farm manager and I have never been a
fund manager you see some of the people
supporting you in this campaign
penny Morden Bernhard Jenkin have gone
on the record and said one of your great
strengths
that you do have experience managing
billions of paddy but that's correct
because that is in in in my roles the
budgets that that the business is
responsible for so I think I think
there's a misunderstanding here if you
are a fund manager you are deciding
investment decisions which stocks to buy
when in fact the owners of those funds
are people who've got their pensions or
their Isis their life savings and so on
tied up in funds that you as a fund
manager are then managing but the
business itself so whether it's Invesco
perpetual or Barclays it has a budget
for what it is spending on developing
those relationships traveling to see
clients and supporting product
development paying the staff in the team
and so on and then of course in banking
you also have massive trading lines and
exposures to different clients so
there's different aspects of it and and
so none of my colleagues have
misrepresented that I was managing
investments on behalf of pensioners and
savers I was not a fund manager I've
been very clear I've worked in the
markets I have worked in banking I have
worked in funds management as senior
investment officer and head of corporate
governance working very closely with the
chief investment officer so you don't
regret at all how your previous
experience has been presented well
that's that's a sort of slightly odd
question I my CV as I've presented it is
exactly accurate so there's nothing to
regret
you know my CV is is accurate that I've
absolutely set out the jobs that I've
done but as I say you know I missed out
my job at the weekend in Sainsbury's so
you know if I can understand people say
well you haven't done this you haven't
said that but I mean where do you stop
you know I could I could add all manner
of work experience and so on if that was
helpful
why wouldn't you publish your tax return
yet so I've been very clear this is
about protecting my colleagues so I
genuinely think that MPs are subject to
often too much pressure to put out every
single bit about their private lives
to be Prime Minister yes but that's very
different you see if I'm in the Fiesta -
yes yes no exactly and if I'm in the
final - I've made very clear I will be
very happy and I will immediately
publish my tax returns but this is a
point of principle I don't think that
the fact that somebody wants to stand
for a position means that they should
immediately allow people access to
everything about them so this is a point
of principle what I would add is my tax
returns are actually extremely boring
says it's going to be a big
disappointment if I get the opportunity
tomorrow to publish them but some
nevertheless it is a point of principle
but did you use a jersey branch of an
investment bank to borrow against the
value of some property that we have so I
have I had a mortgage which I shopped
around for the cheapest deal and at the
time it was being offered by a bank a UK
bank who booked it to Jersey now the
same way Laura if you buy a book from
Amazon you might find its books in
Luxembourg that doesn't make you a tax
avoid and it doesn't mean that you did
it deliberately okay so I think let's
just be clear about this they booked it
in I can't remind it was Jersey and then
subsequently they decided to book it in
London and so you know that that I think
is that is the story why do you think
for our members of our audience who
might not be familiar with you yet as
simply as you can why do you think
you're the right person for the job
I rap I am a real optimist I really
believe that our best years lie ahead of
us and that in leaving the EU we can
really make a success of our country you
know we have so much going for us we're
one of the world's biggest economies you
know we speak the world's international
business language we've got historic
trading links right across the world so
I'm a huge optimist and I believe we
need to seize that and make the most of
the opportunities and you said that your
rally this morning you believed in
prosperity not austerity were you
suggesting that you would slow down the
government's current planned reductions
in public spending I'm completely
committed to the need to get rid of our
deficit there's no doubt about that you
know I mean we we absolutely have to get
our house in order but for me what we
need is a great deal of fiscal stimulus
to make sure that we
that the UK is open for business that we
attract foreign direct investment that
we give businesses certainty about the
the opportunities that there are to
invest that we invest in UK skills so we
up skill our workforce and so on so in
that regard I'm very much in tune with
the with the work that our Chancellor is
already doing you've just said you'd
argue for a fiscal stimulus so we do
borrow now to invest to help the economy
through what might be a bumpy time as we
live these specific policy decisions
would be absolutely necessary to promote
the UK now it's not necessarily
borrowing more or you know or or
changing our actual current account
status but what it will be about is
negotiating free trade being seen to be
negotiating with other countries around
the world with fast-growing economies to
make sure that we can seize the
opportunities it will be about giving
certainty about our negotiations with
the EU to make sure that we have the
that the clearest signs for business
that the UK is absolutely fine that our
economy and our fundamentals are still
strong but you did suggest there that
you might argue for a fiscal stimulus
and that does mean potentially not
necessarily yet potentially but
eventually or in order to it yes
potentially but you know I'm not making
specific policy commitments here in
terms of a couple of other policies just
quickly would you approve the expansion
of the runways at Heathrow I think we
need a very early decision you know I
think part of the whole agenda of being
open for business is about making sure
that people can get here and also get
there so yes we need an early decision
so that that would be my top priority
but again I'm not making a commitment
here and now so whichever it would be
you've got to get on with it yes what
about a trident vote so Teresa mayors
committees to holding a vote on renewing
the nuclear yes Heron this summer yeah
and I mean I came into politics because
of a real childhood concern about the
Cold War and so to me the importance of
the nuclear deterrent is actually sort
of really ingrained in me
and so you know again I don't want to
make a policy commitment as to which
date I would be doing this but I do want
to be very clear I see our nuclear
deterrent is absolutely core insurance
for our national security and finally if
I may becoming Prime Minister is about
your whole life yeah that includes also
your family life if I can ask what do
your family think about you running for
the most important job in the country so
my family are incredibly supportive I
have a very close enormous family and
they're all incredibly supportive my two
elder sons are completely excited about
it my husband's been totally brilliant I
have a much younger daughter who's just
a bit bit more nervous about it but
generally I think we're all in a good
place and how difficult was it to decide
to run it's very difficult you know it's
a huge decision and at the end of the
day I feel having played a part in
showing this country the prospects for
us outside of the EU I just felt I
needed to put myself forward to offer to
lead the way through it because I really
believe in it so that's what I'm doing
is you know I really do feel a sense of
responsibility and a desire to see it
through and that's what's driving me and
realism thank thanks Laura thank you
